title: MOFCOM provides RMB 50 million grant for Douala Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital Construction Project (linked to #22839, #314, #58705)
description: On August 3, 2009, China's Ministry of Commerce signed a grant agreement -- through China Development Bank (CDB) -- worth RMB 50,000,000 with Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health for the construction of and equipment for the Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital in the city of Douala (Projet de construction et d’équipement de l’hôpital gynéco­obstétrique et pédiatrique de Douala (HGOPD)).  Shanxi Construction Engineering was responsible for the implementation of this project.  Construction for the Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital was completed November 17, 2015, and it was handed over on the same day.  Two interest-free loans from MOFCOM were also provided for this specific project (one worth RMB 30 million, as captured in linked ProjectID#58705, and one worth RMB 50 million, which is captured in linked Project ID#314.  In February 2007, the Chinese Government pledged the provision of expertise on studies for the construction of the Gynaeco-Obstetrics and Paediatric Hospital of Douala worth FCFA 44,800,000 (see linked ProjectID#22839).
staff_comments: The Chinese name of this project is 杜阿拉妇儿医院.MOFCOM is the funder but the grant proceeds were to be disbursed through a CDB account established with a host country bank.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
MOFCOM provides RMB 50 million grant for Douala Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital Construction Project (linked to #22839, #314, #58705)

# Description
On August 3, 2009, China's Ministry of Commerce signed a grant agreement -- through China Development Bank (CDB) -- worth RMB 50,000,000 with Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health for the construction of and equipment for the Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital in the city of Douala (Projet de construction et d’équipement de l’hôpital gynéco­obstétrique et pédiatrique de Douala (HGOPD)).  Shanxi Construction Engineering was responsible for the implementation of this project.  Construction for the Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital was completed November 17, 2015, and it was handed over on the same day.  Two interest-free loans from MOFCOM were also provided for this specific project (one worth RMB 30 million, as captured in linked ProjectID#58705, and one worth RMB 50 million, which is captured in linked Project ID#314.  In February 2007, the Chinese Government pledged the provision of expertise on studies for the construction of the Gynaeco-Obstetrics and Paediatric Hospital of Douala worth FCFA 44,800,000 (see linked ProjectID#22839).
justification: Project is focused on healthcare infrastructure development with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction and equipment for Gyneco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: MOFCOM provides RMB 50 million interest-free loan in November 2009 for unspecified purposes
description: On November 5, 2009, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Cameroon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 50 million loan for unspecified purposes. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 0% interest rate, a 10-year grace period, and a 19-year maturity. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 46.4% disbursement rate.
staff_comments: 1. This loan is not included in the Chinese Loans to Africa Database developed by SAIS-CARI and maintained by the Global Development Policy Center at Boston University.
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
MOFCOM provides RMB 50 million interest-free loan in November 2009 for unspecified purposes

# Description
On November 5, 2009, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Cameroon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 50 million loan for unspecified purposes. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 0% interest rate, a 10-year grace period, and a 19-year maturity. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 46.4% disbursement rate.
justification: Loan with unspecified purposes cannot be classified as having environmental impact

title: China signs Broadcasting Cooperation Accord with Central African Republic
description: On September 10, 2009, Hu Jintao and the Central African Republic President François Bozizé Young signed a protocol under which the two sides agreed to strengthen cooperation in the field of radio and television, including the exchange and training of personnel. An updated status and financial value for this project cannot be found.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China signs Broadcasting Cooperation Accord with Central African Republic

# Description
On September 10, 2009, Hu Jintao and the Central African Republic President François Bozizé Young signed a protocol under which the two sides agreed to strengthen cooperation in the field of radio and television, including the exchange and training of personnel. An updated status and financial value for this project cannot be found.
justification: Project focuses on media cooperation and personnel training without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Strengthening cooperation in radio and television, exchange and training of personnel

title: China sends three agricultural experts to the Central African Republic
description: On July 1, 2009, 3 agricultural experts arrived in Bangui for one year of agricultural development training and assistance. This is a part of the Chinese government's project to send hundreds of senior agricultural experts to Africa under the Eight Measures for Africa at the Beijing Summit of the Forum on my country-Africa Cooperation.
combined_text:
# Sector

title: Chinese Government provides grant for establishment of China-CAR Anti-Malaria Center in Bangui
description: In October 2009, the Chinese Government supported the establishment of an anti-malaria center at the Friendship Hospital (Hôpital de l'Amitié) in the capital city of Bangui. The monetary value of this grant commitment is unknown. This project was successfully completed on October 31, 2009.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 中非疟疾防治中心 or 援中非抗疟中心项目. The French project title is Centre China-Centrafrique de Prevention et de Traitement du Paludisme.

evidence: Establishment of anti-malaria center, healthcare focus, no energy-related components

title: China donates 4th batch of anti-malaria drugs to Central African Republic
description: On July 20 and 24, 2009, China and the Central African Republic signed letters of exchange for a batch of antimalarial drugs to be granted to the Central African Republic. The drugs were handed over to the Central African Republic on February 26, 2010, in Bangui. This was the 4th out of 5 batches of drugs as agreed upon at the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum.
combined_text:

# Description
On July 20 and 24, 2009, China and the Central African Republic signed letters of exchange for a batch of antimalarial drugs to be granted to the Central African Republic. The drugs were handed over to the Central African Republic on February 26, 2010, in Bangui. This was the 4th out of 5 batches of drugs as agreed upon at the Beijing Summit of the China-Africa Cooperation Forum.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of antimalarial drugs, healthcare-related project

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for Primary School Construction Project
description: In 2006, at a FOCAC summit, the Chinese Government pledged to fund primary school construction in the Central African Republic (CAR). Then, on August 17, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of CAR signed an RMB 10 million grant agreement for a Primary School Construction Project. This project supported the construction of two primary schools: one in the town of Bimbo (on the outskirts of Bangui) and one in the town of Bégoua (17 km north of Bangui on the road to Boali at Pk 15.   Tianjin Engineering & Construction Corporation and China National Complete Plant Import Export Corporation (Complant) were the contractors responsible for implementation.  A foundation laying ceremony for the primary school in Bégoua (also known as Gbaloko School, Bangui Central Primary School, l’Ecole Gbaloko, Ecole d’Amitié Chine-Centrafrique, and Ecole d'amitié des chinois) took place on December 31, 2007. Then, on January 9, 2008, Complant signed a construction contract. The primary school in Bégoua was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on October 13, 2009.  It consists of 6 classrooms, a reading room, a teacher's office, a principal's office and some ancillary facilities for up to 300 students.  It was later repaired in 2017 with Chinese government assistance (see #55715). A formal handover ceremony for the primary school in Bimbo took place on April 8, 2009.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 中非共和国小学校项目 or 援建的友谊小学校项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for Primary School Construction Project

# Description
In 2006, at a FOCAC summit, the Chinese Government pledged to fund primary school construction in the Central African Republic (CAR). Then, on August 17, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of CAR signed an RMB 10 million grant agreement for a Primary School Construction Project. This project supported the construction of two primary schools: one in the town of Bimbo (on the outskirts of Bangui) and one in the town of Bégoua (17 km north of Bangui on the road to Boali at Pk 15.   Tianjin Engineering & Construction Corporation and China National Complete Plant Import Export Corporation (Complant) were the contractors responsible for implementation.  A foundation laying ceremony for the primary school in Bégoua (also known as Gbaloko School, Bangui Central Primary School, l’Ecole Gbaloko, Ecole d’Amitié Chine-Centrafrique, and Ecole d'amitié des chinois) took place on December 31, 2007. Then, on January 9, 2008, Complant signed a construction contract. The primary school in Bégoua was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on October 13, 2009.  It consists of 6 classrooms, a reading room, a teacher's office, a principal's office and some ancillary facilities for up to 300 students.  It was later repaired in 2017 with Chinese government assistance (see #55715). A formal handover ceremony for the primary school in Bimbo took place on April 8, 2009.
justification: Project focuses on primary school construction, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Construction of two primary schools with educational facilities, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese medical team treats Pygmie patients
description: On July 17, 2009, a Chinese medical team treated Pygmie patients in a village near the city of Pisa. The doctors treated a man with neck cellulitis, and returned a week later to treat the wound.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese medical team treats Pygmie patients

# Description

justification: Project is focused on healthcare services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team providing treatment to patients, healthcare focus

title: Team from China-Africa Senior Agricultural Consulting Group consults with Central African Republic Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development
description: On July 2, 2009, a team from China-Africa Senior Agricultural Consulting Group arrived in Bangui to consult with the Central African Republic Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development. The group formulated agricultural development plans and policies and provided policy and technical guidance for agricultural economy and agricultural product processing. It is unknown if any projects have resulted from the consultation, and it is unclear when exactly the team left the Central African Republic.
combined_text:

It is unknown if any projects have resulted from the consultation, and it is unclear when exactly the team left the Central African Republic.
